vectorData.altText: 17. A patient presents with skin that is red and dry. What functional component of their peripheral nerves is not functional?

That's right!  The sympathetic nervous system controls vascular tone and glands of the skin. Without it, blood vessels dilate, making the skin appear red, and glands are nonfunctional, making the skin dry.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
1.2   Sympathetic Innervation of the Body Wall

Remember, at this point (Day 1) in your anatomy training, you are learning about the innervation of the container, not the contents.  
Remember that the targets of the autonomic nervous system in the body wall and limbs are threefold: vascular smooth muscle, and in the skin, arrector pili muscle      and glands     .
These targets in the body wall and limbs are innervated exclusively by the sympathetic nervous system.  
There is no parasympathetic innervation of the body wall and limbs.
Recall that the sympathetic outflow from the CNS to all peripheral targets originates in the spinal cord, between levels T1 and L2. From here, sympathetic outflow must be distributed throughout the walls of the container, from “stem to stern”     . How this happens is the topic of the next three slides…..
and also to its visceral contents, but that is a story for another day.
